text: - [Instructor] Hello, and welcome
to the Amazon Sample email Service
deliverability learning series.
My name is Alaa.

I'm a senior cloud
support engineer at AWS.
I help customers to understand the
email deliverability best practices

with a primary focus on
eBooks deliverability.

Amazon SES is a cloud
email service provider
that can integrate into any application
for bulk email sending.

Senders from small startups
to large enterprise accounts,
can use SES to reach their customers.

But getting messages to
the recipient's inbox
over the long term can be tricky.

Understanding deliverability
best practices

and what mailbox providers
expect from bulk senders is a key
to getting messages to a customer inbox.

Today's topic is about the
bulk sender requirements

that were implemented by Google
and Yahoo in February 2024.

These requirements center
around E-mail best practices
with a focus on domain authentication
and alignment, spam complaint rates,
and one-click unsubscribe functionality.
While these standards
and best practices have been recommended
and in place for many years, Google
and Yahoo are leading an effort

to enforce these requirements
at a wider scale.

In this video, we will do a
deep dive into the specifics

that surrounds these
bulk sender requirements

and what impact they may
have on Amazon SES customers.

Our discussion of the bulk
sender requirements will include
the following topics.
First, we will discuss a brief summary
of the bulk sender requirements.

Next, we will review the basics
of domain authentication.

Then, we will discuss the
one-click unsubscribe mechanism
as also known as easy unsubscribe.

Lastly, we will discuss how
to monitor spam complaints

to stay within the spam
complaint threshold.

Let's start with the
bulk sender requirements.

The bulk sender requirements
fall into three main topics.

The first topic is domain
authentication and alignment.

The second topic is to provide
an easy way for a recipient
to unsubscribe from bulk mail.

This is also known as
one-click unsubscribe
and easy unsubscribe.

The third is related
to spam complaint rates
with a recommendation that you

as a sender should keep the
complaint rate below 0.1%.
There are many factors

that could result in your
messages being classified as bulk
by any mailbox provider.
Volume over 5,000 messages per day is
one factor, but the primary factor

that mailbox providers use
is in whether the recipient
actually wants to receive that email.

If you are not sure if your
mail is considered bulk,
monitor your spam complaint rates.
If the complaint rates are high

or growing, it's a sign that
you should offer an easy way
for recipients to unsubscribe.

Domain authentication is
the second topic discussed
today in this video.
Domain authentication consists

of security protocols that
verify a sender has permission

to send from a specific IP
address and domain names.

This authentication
security protocols include:
Sender Policy Framework or SPF
Domain Key Identified Mail or DKIM

and Domain Based Message
Authentication Reporting
and Conformance or DMARC.

SPF is an email validation
standard that's designed
to prevent email spoofing.
Domain owners use SPF

to tell email providers
which servers are allowed
to send email from their domains.
The second protocol is DKIM.

It's an email security
standard designed to make sure
that any email that claims

to have come from a specific
domain was indeed authorized
by the owner of that domain.

It uses public key
cryptography to sign an email

with a private key, so
recipient servers can then

use a public key published
to a domain's DNS to verify

that parts of that email
have not been modified
during the transit.
The third protocol is DMARC.

It's an email authentication
protocol that uses SPF

and DKIM to detect the
email spoofing and phishing.
In order to comply with DMARC,
messages must be authenticated
through either SPF or DKIM,
but ideally when both are used with DMARC,
you will be ensuring the highest level

of protection possible
for your email sending.

Mailbox providers will
require domain aligned
authentication with DKIM and SPF,

and they will be enforcing
the DMARC policies

for the domain used in the
"from" header of messages.

For example, gmail.com will
be publishing a quarantine

DMARC policy, which
means that unauthorized
messages claiming to be from Gmail
will be sent to junk folders.
Amazon SES customers must adhere
to the domain authentication requirements

by doing the following: first,
adopt domain identities.
Amazon SES customers who currently rely
primarily on email address identities

will need to adopt
verified domain identities

to achieve better deliverability
with mailbox providers.

By using a verified
domain identity with SES,

your messages will have a
domain aligned DKIM signature.

You should also configure
a custom "mail-from" domain
to align your domain with SPF

and further comply with
sending best practices.

Please see the links to
the domain verification

and custom mail-from in
the notes below this video.
Support easy unsubscribe is our

third topic today for
bulk sender requirements.
Bulk senders are expected to include a
mechanic to unsubscribe by adding an easy
to find link within the message.

The February 2024 mailbox
provider rules will require

senders to additionally add
one-click unsubscribe headers
as defined by RFC-2369,
and RFC-8058.

These headers make it
easier for the recipients
to unsubscribe,

which reduce the rate at
which recipients will complain
by marking multiple messages as spam.

To clarify more on adding
one click unsubscribe headers
to the message you send,

Amazon SES customers sending
bulk messages will need

to implement an easy way for
recipients to unsubscribe,

which they can do using the
SES subscription management

feature, or by adding the
accessory email headers.

Mailbox providers are
requiring the large senders
to give recipients the ability

to unsubscribe from
bulk email in one click
using the one-click unsubscribe header.

In situations where you have
an active preference center,

it's also accepted for the
unsubscribed link in the message

to direct the recipient to a
landing page for the recipient
to confirm their opt-out preferences.

Gmail and Yahoo both clarify
on the respective postmaster

pages that the one click
unsubscribe requirement has been
enforced in June 2024.
The second step to adhering
to the easy unsubscribe requirements are

to make sure you are
honoring unsubscribe requests
within two days.
This can be achieved
by monitoring your unsubscribe mechanism

and make sure you immediately
remove the recipient's

submitted unsubscribed requests
from your mailing list.
SES has a subscription management feature

that can help keep recipients
on your mailing list
by allowing them

to opt into the topics
they are interested in

and remove themselves from
mailing list on topics
that they are not interested in.

You will need to make sure you
integrate the recipient opt

out preference with the source
of your email sending list.

As a general best practice
related to mailing list hygiene,

it's always good to review
your email list building
practices and make sure

to ensure you are using
responsible email practices
by referring from purchasing email lists,

safeguarding opt-in forms
from bot app use, verifying

recipient preferences through
confirmation messages,

and abstaining from automatically
enrolling recipients in

categories that were
not explicitly requests.

Having good list hygiene by
sending only to confirmed

opt-in recipients is
the best way to ensure

that you don't have high
spam complaint rates,

which will keep your
complaint as you adhere
to the bulk sender requirements.

The last requirement will be
discussed in this video today

is spam complaint
monitoring and management.

Mailbox providers will
require that all senders
to keep a spam complaint rate below 0.3%

to avoid having their
email treated as a spam
by the mailbox providers.
There is a couple of steps you need
to follow as an Amazon SES customer

to meet the spam complaint
rate requirement.

First is to enroll with
Google Postmaster tools

to monitor the spam complaint
rates for Gmail recipients.
Gmail recommends spam complaint rates
to stay below 0.1%.
If you send to a mix of Gmail recipients

and recipients under
other mailbox providers,
the spam complaint rates reported by Gmail
postmaster tools are a good indicator
of your spam complaint rates.
At mailbox providers who do not let
you view their spam complaint metrics,
Amazon SES recommends customers
to monitor repetition metrics
and stay below 0.1% complain rate.

Amazon SES offers a feature
called "Virtual Deliverability

Manager" in which customers
can monitor engagement

and delivery performance across
multiple mailbox providers.
This includes bounce and complain rates

along with key engagement
and delivery metrics,

which can be filtered
by configuration set,
domain identity, mailbox provider,

or even down to the
individual message level.
To summarize, the bulk sender requirements
introduced by mailbox providers, Gmail

and Yahoo, are a major
shift in direction by two

of the largest mailbox
providers in the world.

Both are emphasizing domain
aligned authentication,
keeping spam complaint under 0.1%,

and providing recipients with
an easy unsubscribe option.

The expectation is that many
mailbox providers will begin
to implement similar standards aligning
with bulk sender requirements

and implementing email
deliverability best practices across
your email program will provide you

with a long lasting
communication mechanism
to reach your users and customers.
Amazon SES has published documentation

and guidance related to the
bulk sender requirements,
including email best practice topics

and a blog outlining the bulk
sender requirements changes.

These resources can be found
in the summary of this video.

This is the end of the Amazon
SES Email Deliverability

Learning Series focused on
bulk sender requirements.
If you have any comments,

please post them in the
comment section below.
